flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • 1/4" x 1" piece of basswood, 24 inches long
  • 1/2" x 1/2" piece of basswood, 24 inches long
  • sturdy wire, to the length of your shelf plus about two inches (I used 28-gauge)
  • wood nails, 2- to 3-inches long
  • Wood screws
Tools
  • Electric or Hand Saw
  • Hammer
  • Needle Nose Pliers
  • Paint and brushes
  • Screwdriver, medium

parts.text: 1/4" x 1" piece of basswood, 24 inches long
parts.notes: one for each length of shelving

parts.text: 1/2" x 1/2" piece of basswood, 24 inches long
parts.notes: one for each length of shelving

parts.text: sturdy wire, to the length of your shelf plus about two inches (I used 28-gauge)

lines.text: Comic books are tough to store: the traditional boxes are ugly, and shelving them is super-inconvenient. So, inspired by how they're displayed in stores, I tossed off these simple shelves in just over an hour.
lines.text_raw: Comic books are tough to store: the traditional boxes are ugly, and shelving them is super-inconvenient. So, inspired by how they're displayed in stores, I tossed off these simple shelves in just over an hour.

lines.text: If you decide to build yourself a set of these shelves (they’d be great for displaying magazines, too!), you don’t necessarily need to have wall or molding abutting the ends—I think they’d work great free-floating or end-to-end on a longer section of wall.
lines.text_raw: If you decide to build yourself a set of these shelves (they’d be great for displaying magazines, too!), you don’t necessarily need to have wall or molding abutting the ends—I think they’d work great free-floating or end-to-end on a longer section of wall.

lines.text: You’ll need (for each section of shelving):
lines.text_raw: You’ll need (for each section of shelving):

lines.text: one 1/4 x 1-inch piece of basswood, 24 inches long (your front slats)
lines.text_raw: one 1/4 x 1-inch piece of basswood, 24 inches long (your front slats)

lines.text: one 1/2 x 1/2-inch piece of basswood, 24 inches long (your base piece)
lines.text_raw: one 1/2 x 1/2-inch piece of basswood, 24 inches long (your base piece)

lines.text: sturdy wire, to the length of your shelf plus about two inches (I used 28-gauge)
lines.text_raw: sturdy wire, to the length of your shelf plus about two inches (I used 28-gauge)

lines.text: two wood nails, 2- to 3-inches long two wood screws
lines.text_raw: two wood nails, 2- to 3-inches long two wood screws

lines.text: Tools required:
lines.text_raw: Tools required:

lines.text: Paint and brushes, if you like. Needle-nose pliers. A small hand saw (if you need to cut wood to length). Hammer. Screwdriver
lines.text_raw: Paint and brushes, if you like. Needle-nose pliers. A small hand saw (if you need to cut wood to length). Hammer. Screwdriver

lines.text: Cut and paint the wood (about 40 minutes, including drying time).
lines.text_raw: Cut and paint the wood (about 40 minutes, including drying time).

lines.text: I painted the flat slats on all sides, though only the top, front, and bottom will be visible to a casual observer.
lines.text_raw: I painted the flat slats on all sides, though only the top, front, and bottom will be visible to a casual observer.

lines.text: I only painted the top and bottom of the thicker pieces, though only the bottoms will be visible.
lines.text_raw: I only painted the top and bottom of the thicker pieces, though only the bottoms will be visible.

lines.text: I left the front and back sides unpainted as they will be nailed to the flat slats and the wall.
lines.text_raw: I left the front and back sides unpainted as they will be nailed to the flat slats and the wall.

lines.text: If you have a place to do it safely, you could easily use spray paint.
lines.text_raw: If you have a place to do it safely, you could easily use spray paint.

lines.text: Assemble the shelves (five minutes).
lines.text_raw: Assemble the shelves (five minutes).

lines.text: Position your long nails approximately a half-inch from the end of each slat, a quarter-inch from the bottom of the shelf (that means centered in the thicker base).
lines.text_raw: Position your long nails approximately a half-inch from the end of each slat, a quarter-inch from the bottom of the shelf (that means centered in the thicker base).

lines.text: Use my photos as a guide. Drive the nail through the flat piece and nearly all the way into your base piece.
lines.text_raw: Use my photos as a guide. Drive the nail through the flat piece and nearly all the way into your base piece.

lines.text: Hang the shelves (5-10 minutes).
lines.text_raw: Hang the shelves (5-10 minutes).

lines.text: Make sure that the shelves are level, and that there is at least a foot of space between them. Use your tallest comic or magazine as a guide. There should be at least two inches of space between the top of the book and the bottom of the shelf above it.
lines.text_raw: Make sure that the shelves are level, and that there is at least a foot of space between them. Use your tallest comic or magazine as a guide. There should be at least two inches of space between the top of the book and the bottom of the shelf above it.

lines.text: Measure twice, bang once: when you’re certain of the positioning, hammer the nails completely thrrough and into the wall.
lines.text_raw: Measure twice, bang once: when you’re certain of the positioning, hammer the nails completely thrrough and into the wall.

lines.text: If you like, daub some paint over the nail heads to hide them. (Forgive the condition of the walls; my apartment building was built in 1888!)
lines.text_raw: If you like, daub some paint over the nail heads to hide them. (Forgive the condition of the walls; my apartment building was built in 1888!)

lines.text: Hang the wire reinforcements (about 15 minutes).
lines.text_raw: Hang the wire reinforcements (about 15 minutes).

lines.text: Use your needle-nose pliers to create a small loop in the wire, large enough for a wood screw. I experimented with wide-head nails, but trust me on the screws.
lines.text_raw: Use your needle-nose pliers to create a small loop in the wire, large enough for a wood screw. I experimented with wide-head nails, but trust me on the screws.

lines.text: Start a hole by hammering the tip of the screw into the wall six inches above the top of each shelf: high enough to bear weight, but low enough to accommodate “mini” comics.
lines.text_raw: Start a hole by hammering the tip of the screw into the wall six inches above the top of each shelf: high enough to bear weight, but low enough to accommodate “mini” comics.

lines.text: Make the wire as snug as you can, using the tension from screwing in the screws to assist.
lines.text_raw: Make the wire as snug as you can, using the tension from screwing in the screws to assist.

lines.text: Fill the shelves with comics! (Time: as long as it takes to curate.)
lines.text_raw: Fill the shelves with comics! (Time: as long as it takes to curate.)

lines.text: That’s it! You’ve built some seriously impressive-looking custom comic book or magazine shelves in less than two hours.
lines.text_raw: That’s it! You’ve built some seriously impressive-looking custom comic book or magazine shelves in less than two hours.

guide.summary: Build some seriously impressive-looking wall-mounted custom comic book or magazine shelves in less than two hours and spend less than $10.
